awd_titl_txt: RET Site: Reinvigorating Energy Teaching (RET) via Research with Engineers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to leverage the National Science Foundation's (NSF) Directorate for Engineering (ENG) supporting Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering and Computer Science program in order to establish a new RET site and implement a synergistic, triangular partnership between higher education, the public school system, and energy-related industry in the Louisville, KY metro area. The partnership includes faculty from the Colleges of Engineering and Education at the University of Louisville (UofL) host institution and the Jefferson County Public School (JCPS) system district. Select science teachers from JCPS will participate in a six-week summer experience working with UofL engineers on energy-related research and education. These teachers will utilize this experience to modify and augment existing science curriculum for the following academic school year and beyond. Energy represents a unifying theme across all scientific domains. Energy describes physical interactions within essentially all scientific systems, and crosses all disciplinary scientific boundaries. The high school teachers will strengthen their perspectives on engineering research, particularly with respect to variations in engineering design, a topic that is part of the high school science standards in Kentucky. They will also have an immersion experience over the 6 weeks of summer that will give them additional ideas and examples of real-world uses and explorations in energy engineering - useful context for incorporating into their existing high school courses. The engineering faculty and graduate students will benefit from a deeper understanding of the context and goals of high school science teaching - schools from which many of the entering engineering students have matriculated. In a context of energy-related environmental, political, and economical concerns of the modern world, experiences to support a stronger energy-literate culture are helpful for all. Subsequent improvements to high school student understandings of fundamental energy concepts and engineering design principles are expected to have a positive impact on student interest in STEM-related careers. 

The project is to take place over a 3-year period, with 10 JCPS high school science teachers each year participating in the summer energy engineering research labs, and using those experiences to inform their teaching of high school students. The learning experience(s) of the teachers take place in a research-intensive, laboratory-based setting and includes JCPS teachers, practicing engineers from UofL, and representatives from local energy-related industry during a 6-week summer session. Also during the summer session, under the guidance of UofL project personnel, teachers will develop curricular modules informed by their RET experience that will afterwards be incorporated into their classroom practice during the following academic year. Instruction for this RET experience will be focused predominantly on energy science and research, and high school engineering education. Additionally, key aspects of the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) and engineering design (including the criticality of teamwork and communication) will be featured throughout the program and applied to energy-related activities in an effort to support teacher understanding of energy science. Undertakings during the summer session will be a mix of individual- and cohort-based, and will include research experiences, pedagogical planning, industry presentations and tours, and curriculum development. Teacher support from project personnel will be continuous throughout the academic year(s), and methods have been developed (including website(s), conference presentations and workshops, and social media) to ensure sound dissemination of project deliverables to both the general public and the remainder of the JCPS body.

This project is jointly funded by the Directorate for Engineering (ENG), Division of Engineering Education and Centers (EEC) and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Reinvigorating Energy Teaching via Research Experiences for Engineers (RET via RET) was a 3-year, NSF-funded RET site located at the University of Louisville (UofL) and serving the Louisville, KY metropolitan area. This project was the first (ENG directorate) RET site within the state of Kentucky, and participants included high school science teachers from the city’s very large school district. The primary focus of project-related activities was energy, which represents a unifying theme across all scientific and engineering domains, and included varying professional development, energy-based industry tours, and direct participation in authentic collegiate energy research projects – which were categorized into five additional themes, including energy conversion, energy efficiency, energy storage, energy transfer, and renewable energy. Additional project objectives included (a) deepening high school teachers’ understanding of engineering principles, practices and design, (b) supporting the development of STEM-integrated high school science curriculum aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS), and (c) enhancing ongoing a synergistic relationship among university faculty, local schools, and industry-based personnel.

 

During the RET via RET timeline, the program received over 50 applications and supported 30 science teacher participants, represented by varying years of teaching experience and scientific discipline, 14 females, and six teachers of color. Employing three different sets of 10-teacher cohorts over a three-year period – in conjunction with the fact that each teacher educates approximately 100 students per year – results in no less than 3000 students (indirectly) impacted by the RET experience (10 teachers x 100 students per teacher x 3 different cohorts). Given the fact that the above calculation(s) does not consider subsequent academic school years in which the 30 RET teacher participants will educate new student groups, it can realistically be approximated that tens of thousands of high school students in our partnering school districts have been and will continue to be influenced via this RET endeavor. The broader impacts inherent of a more energy-literate culture have been well-documented, and the partnership between (project leaders from) UofL Engineering and Education faculty resulted in a far more effective translation from the world of engineering to high school classrooms. Helping teachers and students develop an appreciation for the extreme significance of energy and our world allows them to have a more positive, informed impact on society.

After the first two years of project implementation were completed, a conference proceeding summarizing this RET project and associated evaluation was drafted, peer-reviewed and accepted, and presented at the American Society for Engineering Education conference in 2023. Upon full completion of RET via RET, a more detailed practitioner article has been initiated and is expected to be submitted for publication consideration in 2024. Key findings from program evaluation affirms that teacher participants found the program experiences valuable and relevant for both themselves in terms of personal learning as well as valuable for contributing ideas and resources for their future high school students. Supplemental aspects of the program highly valued by teachers were the industry field trips (many to a variety of local utilities) and the “ENGR 111 simulations” grounded in studying fundamental engineering skills that first-year UofL engineering students are introduced to.
